text: Craig Claiborne was known as one of the
most cosmopolitan journalists cooks of
his or any generation but for today's
Times classic we're gonna go back to his
childhood to a Mississippi favorite of
his known as smothered chicken I'm gonna
put some butter in that pan turn the
heat on down to about medium and let it
start melting away while that's
happening I'm just gonna spatchcock this
chicken I'm cutting out the backbone of
the bird in order that I can lay it out
in that pan I'm gonna add some freshly
ground black pepper some salt into the
pan goes our spatchcocked bird onto the
top goes to the plate and on to the
plate goes the five pound weight or
anything really heavy you could wrap two
bricks in foil and use that or cans of
tomatoes it's gonna push down on the
bird and make sure that there is really
a nice connection between the bottom of
this cast-iron pan all that butter and
the skin we're gonna cook this for about
25 minutes and then we're gonna come
back and turn it over and do the other
side we're gonna let this sit for about
another 15 minutes cooking in the pan
like this beautifully cooked
but not completely cooked now look in
this pan we've got a fair amount of fat
from the chicken and from the butter
that we started with I'm gonna pour off
a little bit of this stuff because I
want to have some fat in there to help
form the basis of the gravy hot fat dry
flour this is how you end up making a
roux and you can see how it's bubbling
off I'm gonna hit this with a little bit
of chicken stock so let's stir to
combine and see how we do I want to add
a little bit more
I don't like a thin gravy but I'm not
looking for paste either
that looks pretty fine to me now the
chicken returns to the pan it's now in
there with that gravy and now we're
going to cook it for like 25 minutes
more and that is a classic smothered
chicken there are a number of different
variations on this recipe that Craig
Claiborne provided but this one the most
basic and original the taste of his
childhood is the one that we made today
